items.title: What's going on with the Canada Post strikes?
items.description: More than a month into rotating Canada Post strikes, workers and the businesses that use the national postal service are grappling with uncertainty.

items.title: Halifax student leaders hold rally for N.S. government to address housing crisis
items.description: Student union leaders from Halifax's Dalhousie University held a march downtown today, calling on the province to urgently address the city's housing crisis.

items.title: How the son of Russian spies paved the legal path for B.C. ostrich cull
items.description: In his battle for Canadian citizenship, Alexander Vavilov got an opportunity denied to the owners of B.C.'s Universal Ostrich Farms — a chance to argue his case before Canada's top court. In the process, the son of Russian spies set a legal standard for decision-making "reasonableness" that would doom the B.C. birds six years later.

items.title: Holiday hiring is set to get tighter as small firms say no to staffing up
items.description: Three in four Canadian small businesses in the retail and hospitality sectors said they’re not planning to hire seasonal staff for the holidays, according to a new poll.

items.title: Ostrich cull complete at B.C. farm, flock of birds shot dead, CFIA says
items.description: A Global News camera operator at the scene of the Universal Ostrich Farm said gunshots were first heard around 6 p.m. on Thursday.

items.title: Manitoba Government Adds $1 Million to Accelerate Construction of Park Community Centre and Child-Care Facility in Brandon
Telus sees boost to internet customers as it builds fibre service in Ontario, Quebec
items.description: Telus added 40,000 new internet customers as it expands fibre service into Ontario and Quebec, boosting profit to $493M in Q3 despite softer wireless growth.

items.title: Federal budget cuts to public sector will weaken services, unions warn
Teachers' union taking Alberta government to court over notwithstanding clause
items.description: The Alberta Teachers’ Association has filed a constitutional challenge of a provincial government law that forced educators across the province back to work and imposed a new contract.

items.title: Montreal transit agency says there's been progress in talks with one striking union
items.description: The CEO of Montreal's public transit agency says there is progress in negotiations with one of two unions whose walkouts have disrupted service across the network.

items.title: This Ontario town is on a mission to end homelessness by 2027. Here’s how it's going
items.description: When Sara Pepper was living on the streets of St. Thomas, Ont., a few years back, she says there wasn’t much in the way of support. These days, she says, things are looking brighter — but there's still plenty of work to do.

items.title: Manitoba Government Invests $100,000 to Replace Brandon University Observatory Dome
Manitoba Government Delivers on Promises to Make Communities Safer
Canadian airports brace for ripple effects of U.S. FAA flight cuts
items.description: Hundreds of flight cancellations spread across the U.S. as airlines began complying with the Federal Aviation Administration's unprecedented order to scale down routes nationwide.

items.title: The Canadian government is not interested in preventing nuclear war
On Our Radar: Buddie turns its completely understandable stress into something beautiful
items.description: Guitar bands are back in Vancouver, and it’s beautiful.

items.title: By the numbers: Here's what needs to happen in a budget vote to avoid an election
items.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney’s government was elected just a few seats shy of a majority, meaning the Liberals will need the cooperation of one of the opposition parties to pass its budget.

items.title: Smiths Falls man charged with murder in 2023 death of Elizabethtown-Kitley resident
items.description: A Smiths Falls man has been charged with first-degree murder in the 2023 death of Giles Dagenais in Elizabethtown-Kitley. He remains in custody pending a court appearance.

items.title: Marksmen complete cull at B.C. ostrich farm, CFIA says
items.description: The Canadian Food Inspection Agency says it used professional marksmen to complete a cull of a large flock of ostriches in southern B.C. where avian flu was detected last December, ending a months-long legal battle between the agency and the birds' owners.

items.title: Buying a new car? Hidden cameras show some Ontario dealerships adding extra charges and features
items.description: Marketplace visited 15 car dealerships in the Greater Toronto Area with hidden cameras rolling, posing as customers to see if dealerships honour the price in their ads. We found out some car dealerships add extra charges or features.

items.title: How the Abundance Movement Is Dividing the Left
items.description: Calls for fewer rules and faster building have found a progressive audience, including in the BC government.

items.title: N.S. premier criticizes ‘disgusting' ban on staff wearing poppies in some courtrooms
items.description: 'Disgusting' is how Nova Scotia Premier Tim Houston described the decision not to allow staff to wear poppies in some courtrooms ahead of Remembrance Day.

items.title: Are People Losing Trust in BC’s FOI System?
items.description: The province’s information commissioner says plunging numbers of requests should prompt questions.

items.title: Communities shut water intake from B.C. lake after fuel spill reaches 80,000 litres
items.description: A local official says small communities on Kamloops Lake in British Columbia have been shutting down their intakes from the waterway after it was revealed that more than 80,000 litres of aviation fuel spilled on its shores in a train derailment last weekend.
